App description:
Cloudlands 2 builds off of the fun of playing and building minigolf courses and adds the ability to play full sized golf courses.  Arm yourself with a putter, wedge, and driver and hit the links in the clouds.

- 54-hole single player campaign takes you through the Green Glades, Magic Meadows, and Reaper Ruins.  Play 18 hole mixes of full sized golf and minigolf.

- Level Editor with over 1000 pieces to build and make epic mini golf or full golf holes.  Create and upload your creations to allow other people to play.

- Expect to find a nearly unlimited supply of amazing user created levels.  All existing Cloudlands 1 holes are available to play (2000+).

- Online Multiplayer allows up to 4 players to play together.  Create a room, have your friends join, and off you go.

- Local Multiplayer pass and play allows you and your friends to play together by passing one headset between you.

- In-game voice chat and Oculus Avatars fully supported.

RattleKatJun 30 at 8:21 AM
Far better than expected!

I have put off buying this game because the reviews made it sound borderline unplayable. I am happy to say this is not the case at all. It seems at some point, many people were unable to position themselves correctly over the ball but this issue has since been addressed and it's now relatively easy. Simply press the trigger to bring yourself close to the ball, then rotate using the stick or turn your body. Yes, on occasion you have to shuffle around or teleport a little to get right where you want to be, and it can be fiddly, but it's far from game breaking when you'reused to it. Just ensure your guardian is well set up and occasionally use pass through as you will drift from your starting position.

Once you're used to setting up, the golf itself is quite simple but more than serviceable. PGA this isn't but with the right course, it's an excellent virtual pitch and putt. It's is a little jarring to have to set the ball spin before playing a shot rather than relying on actual club physics but again, not a deal breaker; making sure the weight and direction of your shot are accurate provides enough of a challenge to be immersive and engaging.

The mini golf is also well done but doesn't appeal to me as I like chipping and driving. Fortunately, with thousands of user made courses available, it's easy to download and save your favourites so I have plenty of par 2-5 holes to keep me busy. Plus, making your own courses is very simple and fun so you can never run out of new holes to play.

If, like me, you've been putting off buying this, give it a chance. I've been very pleased. All I do is pick 18 fairly grounded holes, turn the music off and enjoy my private pitch and putt course.

If you can handle a more simplistic approach to golf, you will likely enjoy this a lot.

Id consider myself a fan of the Cloudlands series.
I first played Cloudlands: VR Minigolf as an early build, on a pre-release Vive, in a cubicle with the developers, and it sold me entirely on the concept of VR. I spent a lot of time with this first iteration post-release, vibing out with my closest friends and showing newcomers the magic of VR. And now, they have made a sequel.

Cloudlands 2 expands on the formula of the original by adding larger courses and multiple clubs. Unfortunately, rather than make the game feel larger and more expansive this addition makes me more aware of the limitations of the game. Cloudlands 2 is not Golden Tee, as much as Id like to pretend otherwise. Where it shines is in its ease of use and magical, physics/budget defying minigolf courses. But the focus on expansive levels where you cant judge the distance comfortably to the hole, and wouldnt have the clubs to really show off skills if you could, is just... a little disappointing.

Whether youre a regular golfer" or have never played and just want to have fun with a crazy "gnome map with blades of death trying to pulverize your ball," whether youre creative and want to craft new challenging maps or just want to discover the thousands of maps by others, whether you want to play a relaxing game by yourself or join a party, etc. there is so much content here and so much to do.

I played the original Cloudlands a while back. While it had all the core pieces in place, it very much felt like an indie title. Cloudlands 2 embraces its simple, but colorful polygon design (very Rec Roomish in style) and adds a level of polish over it all. This is the defining Cloudlands experience.
